posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: Does anyone have a solution to reduce backlash from hex gears on the hex bore? The backlash from just a 2 stage reduction is really really noticeable and a pain to work around. We tried shims but they fall out and are a huge pain to replace. I’ve also heard of green loctite to glue the gears onto the shaft, but then how would you be able to replace them? Are there any other solutions to this?
shoving aluminum foil in the bore when you slide the shaft on.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Build season=  lack of sleep, and abundance  of coffee

posts.custom_user_title: Build season=  lack of sleep, and abundance  of coffee

posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: That’s what I meant about shims but they fell out after our first competition and are a huge pain to get on.

posts.name: Brendan Manning
posts.cooked:
random though, but can you potentially glue in some shim stock? or can you put in a longer piece and fold over the ends and then adhere the stock on the main face of the gear? I don’t know if either of those would work, but they seem possible.

*Aluminum foil and shim stock seem to be pretty much the same thing.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
You may be able to 3D print slightly undersize hex spacers/washers that slide on tight to the shaft and prevent the shims from sliding out the side of the gear’s hex bore.

Green loctite usually involves a torch to get off.

posts.name: Silas
posts.cooked: Realistically it is difficult/impossible to remove all backlash from gears. One thing that can help is mounting encoders on the thing that you want them measuring, rather than an intermediate stage. We did this and found that the backlash is acceptable, and the accuracy is good enough. Of course its a bit late in the season, but planetary gears are better accuracy wise, so the MAXPlanetary would probably be your best option in the future.

971 discusses the issue of backlash in some depth in this presentation: Spartan Series/ Mechanical Design for Controllability - Travis Schuh - YouTube

Their alternative to shims is to custom machine hex shafts that are slightly oversize and fit the gears as a light press. If you want to go the custom shaft route with a manual mill as opposed to a cnc, you could also try using a hexagonal 5c collet holder for indexing: https://www.amazon.com/5C-CB-5C-Collet-Block-Set/dp/B0186MD7L2

link_counts.title: Spartan Series/ Mechanical Design for Controllability - Travis Schuh - YouTube

posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: We were planning on using MAXplanetaries initially, but chose not to due to our estimated loads being quite near to their rated static loads.

posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: That might work, we’ll try that out!

posts.name: Aidan McMaster
posts.cooked: Another option is to drill a hole through the gear and the shaft, and then press a pin into the hole.

posts.name: Austin Schuh
posts.cooked:
We have done a lot of using loctite gap filler to bond gears to hex shaft this year.  They come off with a heat gun pretty easily.  The trick is to put the shaft in a spot in the gearbox where it can be removed without having to break the loctite.  For us, this typically means on a hex shaft with turned down ends and between two plates.

We also like using well tensioned chain for our last reduction to also reduce backlash.  It is easy to bolt a plate sprocket to the mechanism.

posts.name: Cameron Earle
posts.cooked: Which number Loctite are you using for this? We have been using 638 this season and found it to be almost impossible to remove even after minutes of pointing a heat gun at it, though we could just be using too much.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
AustinSchuh:

loctite gap filler

Seal and insulate gaps & cracks up to 1” inside or out

Is this what you mean?

link_counts.title: TITE FOAM Gaps & Cracks Insulating Foam Sealant

posts.name: Nicholas Dal Porto
posts.cooked:
You want 680 or 620. We have been liking 680. Like Austin said I don’t think we have a single gear or pulley that we didn’t use gap fill on this season. 680 will fill a gap up to .015" which works well for the typical tolerencing we are seeing on COTS hex parts.

I suggest 75165A679 to make your life easier dispensing.

posts.name: caffel
posts.cooked: All good advice.  I’d suggest looking at the basics too.  Are the shafts actually spaced accurately ?  Shims around the bearings are also useful.  Early AndyMark gearboxes were notoriously noisy and we often used a dremel to remove some aluminium and shift the bearings closer together by a few thousandths.

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked: If your application pushes the limits of the MP, generally using a spur gear on that last stage isn’t going to be a good idea (for 20dp anyways).  Highly recommend a well tensioned chain for the last reduction instead of gears.

posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: Yeah, looking back at this we had a chain reduction for our final stage and the shock resistance it provides is probably enough to protect the planetary in the event of impacts or other dynamic loads.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Seconding pins. They’re reliable and commonly used in very high end applications (Aircraft use pins all the time). Steel roll pins are also really cheap and add virtually no weight. You could also try a really really long cotter pin but those things can be an absolute pain to work with and have an annoying tendency to have a lot of wiggle in them and aren’t particularly strong - I know the aircraft industry uses them mostly just to keep bolts from moving and to keep pins in place, nothing particularly high stress (keeping landing gear bolts from moving is about the highest stress job I can remember they do, the engine is all aircraft safety wire) However instead of loctite I would probably just weld the two together, assuming the materials can be welded (aka, it’s 6000 aluminum alloy or whatever of the however many steel alloys that you can easily weld)
